Jim,

Do you have an alternative interpretation to Genji mon?  

My impression is that the goal of applying the melted sahari to the surface is to produce the appearance of the bottom of a tidal pool or puddle.  Would you agree with that?

This tsuba is very difficult to photograph.  Its surface is very high relief, and the sahari is reflective.  The seller's photos are better than any I've been able to make.  It looks a bit better in person.  It's "mud puddle" surface manages to convey simultaneously a sense of rustic wabe sabe simplicity and a sense that this is a really expensive luxury object which took an awful lot of trouble and skill to produce.  Rusticity as sold at Tiffany's, if you see what I mean.  

David
  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Jim Gilbert 
  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Friday, July 22, 2005 3:35 PM
  Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba school


  David,
  It's sahari as Arnold and Rich have said.  It's not Hazama school sahari work though, which is the flush style of inlay that Arnold mentioned.  I've seen several pieces of exactly this type, but no signed ones.  The plates look like later Myochin work.  On the ones I've seen in person the sahari appeared contemporary with the plate.  It's possible that the sahari could be a later addition, but it's hardly something done to appeal to western taste.

  I don't think that the overlapping squares add up to a genji mon.

  Jim



    Tom,


    I'm probably misusing the term shakudo.  Perhaps it's "melted-on something-or-other zogan."   The tsuba is definitely old.  I do own a nice collection of Tokyo Planning Office beer coasters and paperweights, all made last week.    

    David 
    http://zincavage.org/BrownTsuba.html
